bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, [1941]

div1.p: Kean explains how the letters b and v are used interchangeably in Spanish.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, [1941]
div1.opener:
answerd Truby longhand Sep 15, '41
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept 12
My dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Yours of the 10th has just come and
I must send you a line to ack-
nowledge it & its inclosures. Miss
Wood, who is really married & is
Mrs. W. C. Roper was here for several
hours yesterday, she has your letter
and had no complaint to make about
not seeing the Reed letters. I dont
know why she prefers to use her maiden
name, as she is living with her husband
- like Frances Perkins I suppose.
I was mortified to find in the top
drawer of my desk your letter dated
Sept 2, unopened. I suppose it
came when I was sick and was put
AC
in the drawer to be safe and has
been there very safe indeed for two
days. It is about the various
spellings of the names of the Span-
iards at Camp Lazear. They are them-
selves very casual about the spelling
(as Shakespeare was)- B & V are, as
you know, pronounced alike and
are often used interchangeably
in Spanish. Havana is just as
often spelled Habana for instance
I think your decision is, in each
case, the one I would make.
Benigno & Vicente. When you spell
it as they sign it you certainly cant
go wrong.

I must stop here as I have
a guest
div1.closer: Cordially yours J.R.Kean In Beniño the ~ take the place of the 9
